user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimeBaseGetIdByName:
```c
int32 OS_TimeBaseGetIdByName(osal_id_t *timer_id, const char *timebase_name)
{
    int32          return_code;
    osal_objtype_t objtype;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(timer_id);
    OS_CHECK_APINAME(timebase_name);

    /*
     * Check our context.  Not allowed to use the timer API from a timer callback.
     * Just interested in the object type returned.
     */
    objtype = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(OS_TaskGetId_Impl());
    if (objtype == OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE)
    {
        return OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdFindByName(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE, timebase_name, timer_id);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TimeBaseGetIdByName:
#define OS_CHECK_APINAME(str) OS_CHECK_STRING(str,OS_MAX_API_NAME,OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG)
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdFindByName(osal_objtype_t idtype, const char *name, osal_id_t *object_id)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /*
     * As this is an internal-only function, calling it with NULL is allowed.
     * This is required by the file/dir/socket API since these DO allow multiple
     * instances of the same name.
     */
    ARGCHECK(name, OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND);
    LENGTHCHECK(name, OS_MAX_API_NAME, OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, idtype, name, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        *object_id = token.obj_id;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, const char *name, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch(lock_mode, idtype, OS_ObjectNameMatch, (void *)name, token);
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
void OS_printf(const char *String, ...)
{
    va_list va;
    char    msg_buffer[OS_BUFFER_SIZE];
    int     actualsz;

    BUGCHECK_VOID(String != NULL)

    if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.GlobalState != OS_INIT_MAGIC_NUMBER)
    {
        /*
         * Catch some historical mis-use of the OS_printf() call.
         *
         * Typically OS_printf() should NOT be called before OS_API_Init().
         *
         * This was never guaranteed to work, particularly on a VxWorks
         * deployment where the utility task was enabled.
         *
         * However, some PSPs do this, particularly those that used POSIX
         * where it happened to work (because OS_printf just called printf).
         *
         * As a workaround, use the OS_DEBUG facility to dump the message,
         * along with a clue that this API is being used inappropriately.
         *
         * If debugging is not enabled, then this message will be silently
         * discarded.
         */
        OS_DEBUG("BUG: OS_printf() called when OSAL not initialized: %s", String);
    }
    else if (OS_SharedGlobalVars.PrintfEnabled)
    {
        /* Format and determine the size of string to write */
        va_start(va, String);
        actualsz = vsnprintf(msg_buffer, sizeof(msg_buffer), String, va);
        va_end(va);

        if (actualsz < 0)
        {
            /* unlikely: vsnprintf failed */
            actualsz = 0;
        }
        else if (actualsz >= OS_BUFFER_SIZE)
        {
            /* truncate */
            actualsz = OS_BUFFER_SIZE - 1;
        }

        msg_buffer[actualsz] = 0;

        OS_ConsoleWrite(OS_SharedGlobalVars.PrintfConsoleId, msg_buffer);
    }
}
...
#define OS_MAX_API_NAME 20
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
The fragments selected are all locations where the provided 'name' / 'timebase_name' pointer is checked, passed, or used in operations that commonly employ <string.h> functions (length checks, name matching). These require investigation to ensure any strlen/strncpy/strcmp/etc. used internally cannot read or write past object bounds.

Other code fragments in the provided snippets do not need investigation for Rule 21.17: the pointer-check macro OS_CHECK_POINTER expands to a BUGCHECK and does not invoke string.h functions; OS_ObjectIdRelease and OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch callers shown do not themselves perform string operations; OS_printf uses vsnprintf/stdio functions (not functions from <string.h>) and contains explicit truncation logic (bounds-aware) and a null-check via BUGCHECK_VOID, so it is not relevant to this <string.h>-specific rule. Any remaining macros or functions not shown (e.g., the actual definitions of OS_CHECK_STRING, ARGCHECK, LENGTHCHECK, OS_ObjectNameMatch, or OS_ObjectIdGetBySearch) are precisely the items that must be inspected by the investigators — which is why calls/sites that provide the 'name' pointer to them are reported above.
